channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Joe Rogan said he had declined several times to have Donald Trump on his influential Spotify podcast. “I don’t want to help him,” said Rogan, who has amplified Covid-19 misinformation and is popular with many Trump supporters. https://t.co/OLpILX1VBN

The Gun Violence Archive has counted more than 300 mass shootings in the U.S. so far in 2022. Of those shootings, 15 involved four or more fatalities, including the one in Highland Park on Monday. https://t.co/pxSprXPbLt https://t.co/KLCucX3geo

A New York judge held one of the world’s largest real estate firms — which appraised several of Donald Trump’s properties — in contempt of court amid a civil investigation into whether the former president falsely inflated the value of his assets. https://t.co/LTiM3QWOFd
Nuclear power is winning political converts in the U.S., amid obstacles facing clean energy goals and new electricity demands. https://t.co/QNJ3VSSTYO

Breaking News: Pat Cipollone, the former White House counsel to Donald Trump who repeatedly fought Trump's efforts to overturn the 2020 election, has agreed to testify by Friday before the Jan. 6 committee. https://t.co/wQjxzGsuCV
The Justice Department sued Arizona over a new Republican-imposed law requiring proof of citizenship to vote in a presidential election. https://t.co/5ArlDAir0p

Western pygmy possums don’t usually live with western spiny-tailed geckos. But a nest box in Australia seems to have become a comfortable, if slightly crowded, home for the new roommates. https://t.co/hxeKaDqkul https://t.co/tQ2vlvNGyi
Breaking News: European lawmakers voted to classify some gas and nuclear energy projects as “green,” a landmark decision that could be replicated elsewhere. https://t.co/2SwX4ZjT35

Newly signed legislation will make it more difficult to obtain a handgun license and buy high-capacity rifles in New Jersey, the latest in a patchwork effort by states to work around a sweeping Supreme Court ruling aimed at dismantling them. https://t.co/q8tJeKD2bb

A Colorado funeral home operator who was accused of stealing body parts and selling them to medical and scientific buyers, making hundreds of thousands of dollars in what the authorities called an “illegal body part scheme,” pleaded guilty to mail fraud. https://t.co/j5l9YgvtmZ

The Lake County coroner, Jennifer Banek, read aloud the names of six of the seven victims of the shooting in Highland Park, Illinois, at a news conference on Tuesday afternoon.
Follow our live updates. https://t.co/uWd81Zgu5e https://t.co/X7coQCM4qX

Sara Kruzan was 16 when she killed a man who she said sexually abused and trafficked her for years. She served nearly two decades in prison, and her case reignited criticism of the way courts treat survivors of abuse. https://t.co/K9yAb5NNLB
The governors of New York and New Jersey agreed to split the local costs of train tunnels under the Hudson River and a new bridge. https://t.co/RBldj634Qn

To serve this Georgian dish known as khachapuri adjaruli, you drop an egg yolk and some cold butter into the molten cheese and stir it into a gooey, stretchy cheese puddle.
Full recipe: https://t.co/8OlWy5Qd16 https://t.co/mbVB0H3nZE
Rudy Giuliani, Lindsey Graham and several other Donald Trump allies were subpoenaed in Georgia’s criminal inquiry into election interference. https://t.co/BaiBvtu6Gu https://t.co/JuwaLAQ6GC
Breaking News: Rudy Giuliani, Lindsey Graham and several other Donald Trump allies were subpoenaed in Georgia’s criminal inquiry into election interference. https://t.co/qwi1l2UbSq

Breaking News: Two British ministers, Rishi Sunak and Sajid Javid, unexpectedly quit, leaving Prime Minister Boris Johnson battling for his political survival amid a series of scandals. https://t.co/Wdbmp9qtOT

Breaking News: The suspect in the shooting in Highland Park, Illinois, during a Fourth of July parade planned the attack for weeks and wore women's clothing as a disguise to escape, officials said. https://t.co/s22971eZFr

Nearly a year after El Salvador’s president made Bitcoin a national currency, his bet on the digital coin appears to be backfiring.
The value of the government’s crypto holdings has plunged, and the country is running out of cash. https://t.co/4O3ICt8t4h

High-profile Russians deemed insufficiently patriotic are being detained by security forces.
The message sent by these arrests: Nearly anyone is now punishable in Vladimir Putin’s Russia. https://t.co/IKQohGlYKL

Even in a country battered from the constancy of mass violence — at grocery stores, elementary schools, street corners — the shooting at a parade in Highland Park, Illinois, proved shocking. Six people were killed, including a 76-year-old grandfather. https://t.co/QMysERTqsZ https://t.co/gqzY86xLm2

Demaryius Thomas, a star NFL player, had CTE when he died in December at 33, doctors announced. But the posthumous diagnosis alone does not explain what role football had in his quick decline. https://t.co/5P26wqXNBE

Lauren Silva helped to rescue a toddler who was lying beneath an unresponsive and bleeding man during the shooting at a Fourth of July parade in Highland Park, Illinois.
“I held him like he was my own,” she said. https://t.co/VmyEHA8jBw

NATO formally approved membership bids for Finland and Sweden. Now, the legislatures of the 30 alliance members will consider ratification, a process that must be unanimous and can take several months at least. https://t.co/lzODZACuaG

Brittney Griner, the WNBA star who has been detained in Russia on drug charges since February, sent a handwritten letter to President Biden asking him not to forget about her.
"I’m terrified I might be here forever," she wrote. https://t.co/sakqIzimPU

Joe Turkel, a character actor who appeared in scores of movies but is best known for two of his final performances — as Lloyd the bartender in “The Shining” and Dr. Eldon Tyrell in “Blade Runner” — died on June 27. He was 94. https://t.co/vsbg8ysHC7

President Biden once again expressed the horror of a nation in a statement, saying he was “shocked by the senseless gun violence” after a gunman killed six people and injured more than three dozen others at a July 4 parade in Highland Park, Illinois. https://t.co/jquXO7m934

U.S. Special Operations veterans are training Ukrainian soldiers near the front lines in the war against Russia and, in some cases, helping to plan combat missions. The crowdfunded volunteers traveled to Ukraine despite warnings from the Pentagon. https://t.co/ivEGsk9Or5

Nicolas Toledo, 76, didn’t want to attend the Highland Park July 4th parade, but his disabilities required him to be around someone full-time.
He was in his wheelchair when the rooftop gunman started firing. He suffered three gunshot wounds, killing him. https://t.co/SBB3a5L66c

Fourth of July celebrations have been canceled in Highland Park, Illinois, and several nearby communities in response to the shooting at Highland Park’s parade, as the police hunted for the perpetrator.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/8fBq4vS6mx

A shooting at a Fourth of July parade in Highland Park, Illinois, sent hundreds of people fleeing for safety. The police said six people were killed and dozens were wounded after a gunman opened fire from a rooftop. https://t.co/2buIjwH98j https://t.co/Hhsq7vv4gJ

Witnesses of the shooting at a Fourth of July parade in Highland Park, Illinois, described scenes of chaos, terror and confusion.
“The streets were just filled with people running, kids crying,” one woman told a local news station. https://t.co/Cp67JV4eIT

A shooting caused hundreds of people to flee for safety from the Fourth of July parade in Highland Park, Illinois, the authorities said. The Lake County Sheriff’s Office urged people to stay away from the area. https://t.co/eAPvRxNX9r

In Ukraine, volunteers with limited training are increasingly heading into the kind of battles that test even the most experienced soldiers. Their bodies are being returned to fill up cemeteries in largely peaceful cities and towns in the country’s west. https://t.co/uh0iYP5Atd https://t.co/qjSGorMTro

Breaking News: Five people were killed and 16 were hospitalized in the shooting at a Fourth of July parade in Highland Park, north of Chicago. The police are still searching for the gunman.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/db3NboaX9j

In Opinion
“If Trump runs again, the Democratic Party had better put its strongest opponent forward to stop him,” Bret Stephens tells Gail Collins in their latest conversation. “God love Biden, but he ain’t it.” https://t.co/mcatlNuZaI

A central theme of Kremlin propaganda about the war in Ukraine is that the country's government and culture are filled with dangerous Nazis. These false claims started on state media, but smaller news sites have gone on to amplify the messages. https://t.co/M7la0G1VIN

Sixty years after the execution of Adolf Eichmann, the Nazi war criminal, his confessions have been aired in a new documentary.
Hours of tape recordings expose Eichmann's visceral, ideological antisemitism and his role in the mechanics of mass murder. https://t.co/2lPxpVKWLI https://t.co/vsqCqmZOHc

News Analysis: Former President Donald Trump has weathered scandals by keeping his intentions under wraps, Peter Baker writes. But recent testimony paints a stark portrait of a man willing to do almost anything to hang onto power. https://t.co/iZosXOem0T

A new generation of women activists opposing abortion rights — often pointed to by anti-abortion leaders as the face of the movement — say they are poised to continue the fight in a post-Roe nation. https://t.co/BoiNtFmvqU

The police chief in Akron, Ohio, said officers shot Jayland Walker more than 60 times. Police reported gunfire from Walker’s vehicle after attempting to pull him over but confirmed he was unarmed at the time he was chased on foot and killed. https://t.co/aL7NLyhuLM https://t.co/JlOJ0BpIq9

Vladimir Zelenko, a self-described "simple country doctor" who rocketed to prominence in the early days of the Covid-19 pandemic when his unfounded treatment using hydroxychloroquine gained White House support, died on Thursday. He was 48. https://t.co/gBxXPKkxZ1

Jayland Walker, a 25-year-old Black man who was killed by officers in Akron, Ohio, suffered more than 60 gunshot wounds but was unarmed, the police chief said. Police released footage that showed officers’ actions but deepened questions around his death. https://t.co/S8bdppq48D

These seven questions will help couples check in, whether they're in a relationship that is still reeling from the pandemic, or long ago dove back into old routines without pausing to touch base. https://t.co/ZsSfAM5CJB https://t.co/88BJEbNeoT

The "American Cancer Society of Michigan" and many other fake charities had the same mailbox at one Staten Island location. Here's how the IRS missed a clear fraud. https://t.co/pHxlBDx500 https://t.co/hLLwtfLzZH

The chief security officer of the Supreme Court has asked that Virginia and Maryland officials enforce laws that would prohibit protests outside the homes of justices after weeks of demonstrations favoring abortion rights. https://t.co/y5sLKmhm05

Breaking News: Several people at a Copenhagen shopping mall have been shot and one person has been arrested in connection with the shooting.
The shooting happened at Field’s, the largest shopping center in Denmark. https://t.co/I9AoeHALSQ

Charles Bausman, a former financial executive who runs websites that promote far-right views, recorded footage in the Capitol for a Russian television producer. Soon after, he fled to Moscow as a "political refugee." https://t.co/GGykX6zOuC

The driver of a truck that could top 350 miles per hour because it was powered by jet engines died after the vehicle crashed while racing two airplanes at an air show in Michigan. https://t.co/ZPiIBOFGyu

For five years, the most famous clock tower in Britain was hidden behind an ugly fortress of scaffolding, its hourly bong rendered mute. But this summer, a sound familiar to Londoners for more than 160 years will again ring out — Big Ben is back. https://t.co/ku5z3w30OF https://t.co/zmGm9Wp1Nu
